turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Show business?

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Yes. It's always fascinated me.  You know, once, when I was a youngster, I went to see Mrs. Leslie Carter in "Zaza." After the play I stood in the alley just to watch her come out.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Well, I'd best be off.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I want to ask you something.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It's about the leopard.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: You're worrying about its killing someone else?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Yes. I want to go out and patrol the town - be everywhere at once - be sure nothing happens to anybody.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Of course. It's the way any decent man would feel in your position.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You know about animals -- their habits -- will it come back?

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: No. I'm quite sure.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: There is no danger at all. It's a wild animal. Do you think a wild animal prefers walls, streets and people when it can get into open country?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: That's right, of course.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Don't feel so concerned, Jerry.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Doc -- something you said the other day --

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It doesn't jibe with this  you told me the leopard would go out into the country - it wouldn't stay in the city 

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Sure -- certainly - but what's that got to do with this?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: That's what I don't understand -- why should it come here -- and why didn't it stay here? It's got trees and bushes here -- outside nothing but cement and asphalt.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Jerry, I talked to you about the habits of an ordinary wild leopard. This leopard is another matter entirely - - a caged animal travelling around with Charlie How Come for years and years.. That's why it kills human beings.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: It doesn't know how to hunt its natural prey.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: But it doesn't eat what it kills.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Caged animals are unpredictable. They're like frustrated human beings. I can't answer your question.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Just a minute, Robles.  Let him go on.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I can understand about the cat killing the first girl. Charlie How Come told me. All that noise and those lights -- scared crazy it would do anything. Last night there was nothing to disturb it. Just a little girl alone in a cemetery.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You know Charlie How-Come?

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: We're old friends.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Come to look around?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: More or less.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: I'll take you about. Got some nice things.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Charlie and I were talking. That's one reason I wanted to see you.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: About Charlie's leopard?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Charlie doesn't think the leopard killed the girl in the cemetery.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Charlie likes his leopard.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It could be a man.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: It could be. Why would a man kill her? For what? It wasn't robbery. It wasn't a crime of jealousy or passion. She had no enemies.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: There are all sorts of men. You get to see some funny ones as a reporter.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: I can understand what you mean - demented men, pathological cases. But what sort of man would kill like a leopard and leave the traces of a leopard?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Some crazy guy.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: But he would have to know about leopards - have access to leopard claws and hair.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: We had given up digging in a certain barrow. I went back and I tried again. I just had a hunch.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: A hunch -- that's all I've got about this leopard thing. It's just a hunch, yet I feel it deep in the stomach. It was a man!

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Yes, but what sort of a man?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: You, Charlie -- you know leopards. You might have had an old claw around somewhere, and perhaps a bit of hair from the cage - eh?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Come on, Charlie. Let's go find another and better suspect.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Don't you want to see the rest of the exhibit?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Some other time.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You must admit it's possible that it might have been a man.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Just barely possible - - yes.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You know a lot. You've taken a lot of fancy courses in colleges and that kind of stuff - - what kind of a man would kill like that?

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: But all those fancy courses were about the dead, Jerry, not the living.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: All right -- the dead, then.  In history there must have been men like that -- men with kinks in their brains --

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Yes. There have been men who kill for pleasure -- strange pleasure. There was Blue Beard in France -- Jack The Ripper in London. It's not uncommon.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: If there were a man like that, with a kink in his brain around here loose, what would he be like.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: To the eye? Like other men.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I don't mean that. How would he act? What would he do?

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: He'd act normally when he was with other people. It would be a man who suffered remorse and even pity when it was all over.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Couldn't you tell a man like that when you saw him?

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: No. He would be a hard man to find, Jerry. Particularly if he were a clever men. He would go about his ordinary business calmly and coolly except when the fit to kill was on him.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You've thought of all this before. You know it isn't the leopard   Don't you?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It was you, Galbraith!

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It was you.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Not! I tell you. No!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You shot the leopard. We know that. You killed Consuelo. You killed Clo Clo. Then tonight --

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: I didn't do anything. She screamed. Something frightened her.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Consuelo screamed too -- and Clo Clo. Why did you do it? Why? Quick. Tell me why?

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: It's better you don't know.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Tell me.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Why do yo&i accuse me? You don't know what you're doing -- you don't understand -- nobody understands --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Tormented -- ? Why?

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: I couldn't rest - I couldn't sleep. All I could see was Teresa Delgado's body -- broken --mangled. I saw it day and night.  It was waiting everywhere I turned.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Then you found the leopard --

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: I didn't want to kill, but I had to. I heard her in the cemetery - talking to the man in the auto --

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Jerry told me you were an expert with animals, Mr. Galbraith. Couldn't you tell where it went?

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: To know where that leopard went -  I'm afraid you'd have to be a leopard and think like a leopard. I was a naturalist. That hardly qualifies me as an expert in hunting down lost leopards. I used to teach zoology in a little freshwater college back East. I gave that up.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: What do you do now?

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: There's a little museum here in town. They've hired me to run it, We've some interesting exhibits of Indian arts and crafts. It's fun -- and I like living here in New Mexico.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Why did you give up teaching?

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Various reasons.  But I can't see why you'd be interested in the rather dusty career of William Galbraith  teacher, naturalist, curator -- when you lead such a gay and exciting life yourself.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: So you see meeting you is a real thrill for me.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Well, I'm hardly Mrs. Leslie Carter whoever she was. In fact, I'm not even much of a success around here particularly after the backfire on Jerry's little publicity stunt with the leopard.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: That was unfortunate.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: That was a calamity!

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Well, I'm next. You won't hear anything like that, Mr. Galbraith.  I'm not a popular favorite since I let the leopard loose.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: I'm sure if you are as talented as you are charming, Miss Walker, you have nothing to worry about.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: I've disturbed	you. I'm sorry -

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Miss Walker -- I didn't expect anyone 

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Of course. Only I'm afraid you'll be cheated. There isn't much of a view of the procession here.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: I thought they came right past here 

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: They do, but -- there are no lights out there - they'll just be shadows -

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Wait 

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: No - really, I can see them -- they're coming now - turn off the lights 

turns.speaker: ROBLES
turns.text: You can go now, Manning. There is no way we can hold you legally responsible.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Thanks, Sheriff.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I haven't done any posse work since last time I rode with Toni Mix at the old Bijou Theatre -- aged six, If you're interested,

turns.speaker: ROBLES
turns.text: Go on foot.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It's not for me.  I'm literally and figuratively a tenderfoot.

turns.speaker: ROBLES
turns.text: That's why it just mauls and tears at them.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Something's wrong with this whole setup --

turns.speaker: ROBLES
turns.text: Yes, there is something wrong. People who want publicity and don't mind how they get it --what risks they make other people run - - what agony and sorrow they bring to other people --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I know all that, chief, and I don't like it any better than you do, but there's something else --

turns.speaker: ROBLES
turns.text: What are you getting at?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Nothing much -- just that it might not be a cat this time.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I've been trying to tell him, Sheriff. He won't listen to me.

turns.speaker: ROBLES
turns.text: Let me get one thing clear. Did Galbraith make a direct accusation?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: No. He was kidding Charlie.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: State hunters?

turns.speaker: ROBLES
turns.text: Professional hunters, who rid the state of cougars.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Yes. The lipstick.

turns.speaker: ROBLES
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Ask Kiki. Ask any woman. Girls don't put on lipstick in the middle of the night on a dark, lonely street unless they're with a man or expecting a man.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Chief, don't you understand what this means?

turns.speaker: ROBLES
turns.text: You think Galbraith found the leopard on the day you went out with the posse.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I'm sure of it!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Galbraith knows something. He as good as said so 

turns.speaker: ROBLES
turns.text: I am not interested in what somebody else thinks. You being me facts and I'll act on them.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: That's a fact, isn't it?

turns.speaker: ROBLES
turns.text: Yes. And I am taking it to headquarters for examination.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You won't go to Galbraith with me?

turns.speaker: ROBLES
turns.text: Offend a reputable citizen and involve the department in a slander suit? No. I'm in office to protect the taxpayers money  not throw it way. Come on, Charlie.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Get it out of here!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Kiki -- he won't hurt you. There's nothing to be afraid of.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Makes no difference. Get him out!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Listen, Kicks, you'll never guess what I've cooked up this tine...

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: That's easy. Me.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I thought -- is Kiki just going to walk on that floor tonight walk out cold before a bunch of gawks who think a Spanish twirler is the greatest thing in life. No. Not my favorite client. She's going to make an entrance this town will never forget!

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: On his back, I suppose.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: No. I thought that might be just a little corny. I want you to lead him in on a leash.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: You're too good to me.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Look, Kicks, have I ever done anything to hurt you?

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: No - not yet.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: And I never will- you know what's between us  we're a thing But this is serious competition.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Get it out of here!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Kiki - he won't hurt you. There's nothing to be afraid of.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Makes no difference.  Get him out.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Listen, Kicks, you'll never guess what I've cooked up this time.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: That's easy. Me.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I thought - is Kiki just going to walk on that floor tonight walk out cold before a bunch of gawks who think a Spanish twirler is the greatest thing in life. No. Not my favorite client. She's going to make an entrance  this town will never forget.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: On his back, I suppose.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: No. I thought that might be just a little corny.  I want you to lead him in on a leash.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: You're too good to me.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Look, Kicks, how long have we known each other?

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: This is l939. Can't you subtract?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Almost three years, isn't it? And have I ever done anything to hurt you?

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: No  not yet.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: And I never will -- you know what's between us - we're a thing -- But this is serious -- big competition.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Clo-Clo?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I thought you might strut this kitten in right in the middle of her act.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You look swell in that threealarm number --

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: The red dress?  No. My black one. Then I'll be just like him.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Are you all right?

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Now look what you've done.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Suppose I slip them a few bucks  for the funeral expenses.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Don't be soft.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I suppose he was trying to make me feel bad.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: And I suppose you don't feel bad!

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Who was the other man?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I don't know  a witness. He seemed to know something about animals -- you know -- expert testimony.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: What did he have to do - look at the body?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: We all, had to look at the body. It was awful, Kiki -- awful!

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Well, does everybody love us now? You've been gone long enough to softsoap twenty editors!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: And did you find the leopard?

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: It must be the altitude  you, bucking around the countryside with a lot of bootandsaddle boys --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: The whole town's in a state, Kiki doors locked, people huddling together like scared sheep nobody on the streets at night 

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Our first real break -- and we throw wild animals at the audience

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Forget it. I'm buying a drink for a fellow who was on the posse with me, a nice guy. Come along he'll get a great kick out of meeting you.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Who is he?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You remember the fellow this morning -- Galbraith. You've got time before the supper show.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: 	As long as my feet held out.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: And not a sign of the leopard?

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: I can use them.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Do they close up every year for this Processionist business?

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: That was nice of Mr. Galbraith.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: He's a nice guy. Vie ought to keep in touch with him.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Pretty. You know -- it's funny but flowers only mean one thing to me now.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I know. Funerals.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Jerry, these flowers aren't really for me 

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You mean you want to take them to the cemetery.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Yes. Do you mind?

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: And she waited here for him?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Robles says it looks that way. Belmonte had already been there and left. They only missed each other by a few minutes.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Why do you want to stay around here? It'll only make you feel badly.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Maybe I want to feel badly.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: That doesn't make sense.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: What else do you care about, Kicks?

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: You. Us.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I'm glad you care about us, Kicks. Sometimes that gets kind of lost in the racket --

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Maybe there ought to be less racket and more us.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Confession. I'm a complete softie. I've been conscience-stricken and worried sick ever since that leopard got away --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: If that's being a softie -- there are two of us.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Kiki -- it wasn't the leopard.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: You're positive of that, aren't you?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Absolutely sure.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: You already know the answer to that. I want this town to be safe and happy again --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I'm no detective. I don't even know how to begin. All I know is I want to do something about all this.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Oh, by the way -- I'm out of cash --

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Didn't you take your cut out of the closing check?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I got into a little crap game.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: That's funny -- I never knew you to lose that much before --

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: As a matter of fact, I'm out of cash myself.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: What! You can't be --

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: I -- I bought some silver jewelry and stuff from Eloise --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Eloise doesn't own enough of anything to make a dent in your pay check, Kicks.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: All right, I'm not ashamed of it! I split it two ways 

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Half to the Delgado family and half to Clo-Clo's family.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: No. No, thanks.  Now we've got to do it ourselves.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: We will 

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Kiki?

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: It's all right. I'm not hurt.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: We stood here once before.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I know -- Teresa -

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: I hated you that day - you and your flip talk - with that little girl lying dead.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I know. What do you think I felt when you said, "don't be soft?"

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Jerry, I want you to be soft. You are soft -- inside - where it matters. I wanted it that day too, but didn't dare tell you.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: We ought to dare to tell each other everything, Kiki -- you and I.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: It's a lovely town - it was until we came and let the leopard loose and all this happened.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Kiki, Galbraith said something to me once, -- something you ought to know. We were talking and he said that people were like that ball on the fountain at the hotel --they got pushed around by things bigger than themselves. That's the way it was with us -- and we were too small to see it that way.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Hot...  These roads all round here, closed to the public... Whys that? Military bases?  Huh. I guess theres space enough for war games... Must be good for business.

turns.speaker: ATTENDANT
turns.text: Must it?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: All those soldiers out there... getting bored, thirsty. Come out here for refreshment or female company perhaps?

turns.speaker: ATTENDANT
turns.text: Aint nobody out there, Mister.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Nobody? Huh!... How come?

turns.speaker: ATTENDANT
turns.text: Maybe for the same reason that made someone somewhere not consider this a spot to build the Getty Museum...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Ha-ha... Yeah...  What about that road back there, though? It says closed to the public, doesnt it?

turns.speaker: ATTENDANT
turns.text: You a tourist?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Thats right.

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Will you please come with me?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: That might depend on where youre going.

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: I am Lawrence, sir. Mr and Mrs De Moraes majordomo. They are expecting you.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: De Moraes? I was asked here by a Mrs Spitz.

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: That would be Mrs De Moraes mother, Sir. Mr and Mrs Spitz are here with their daughter.

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Good afternoon. De Moraess residence.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Could I speak to Carlos or Deborah?

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Im afraid they are out at the moment, sir.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: When will they be back?

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Mr De Moraes is due back from Brazil late this evening. Mrs De Moraes is out and not expected before eight. Do you wish...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: By the way, Laurence, were you here last time your mistresss brother came over? You know, just before he disappeared?

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: I work here, sir. Im here most of the time.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You wouldnt recall if the brothers-in-law left together, would you?

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: You will have to ask Mr De Moraes that, sir.  Would you like a drink while you wait?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: No. Thank you. Ill be fine...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Mrs De Moraes must have taken it hard, eh?  Her brothers death.

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Dial O-O-O on the telephone if you change your mind about the drink, sir.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Now you know why youre here, Mr Lombard.  It might be difficult for someone like you to discern, but we are people of a certain standing.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Appearances can be deceptive, Mrs De Moraes.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: That depends what youre looking at.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Three weeks ago. To borrow money. I wasnt here but he got to my husband, sold him some fancy story about an exhibition of his work and needing money to get new prints made. Carlos handed over £1,000 to get rid of him.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: And that is the last time any...

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Well, Leon does not need money for prints, Mr Lombard. Does his own printing. Wouldnt want anyone to interfere with his Art!  Which, as he subsequently vanished, raises the question: what was the money for? Perish the thought.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What about you, Mrs De Moraes?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: I have too much money to work, Mr Lombard.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Is that why your brother braved coming here to ask you for a loan?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Perhaps it wasnt so brave of him. Had I been here I just might have given him his money, Mr Lombard. One can reap rewards from the strangest of conduct, as someone in your line of work ought to know.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Was it cash, Mr De Moraes?  The £1,000. You gave it to him in cash?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: I wont comment on the time but youll understand if I dont tell you to sit down. Now, spare me the apology and get to the point, will you, Mr Lombard.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Im afraid I have bad news, Mr De Moraes. I have reason to believe your brothers in trouble.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: For your information, Mr Lombard, trouble is possibly the one thing Leon is capable of getting into all by himself. Though I doubt he will not ultimately fail even at that.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I dont know. He seems to delight in so much sisterly love, he might become determined.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Oh-oh! Touché, Mr Lombard! But tell me, what would you know about sisterly love, eh?  No. Dont. You might get confused speaking of things you dont understand and we need you clear- headed, at least until youve done what we are paying you for.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Now you are confusing me, Mrs De Moraes.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Can it be that easy?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Can it be that you want your brother found?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Anything is possible.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I found this at your brothers.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Disney! How inter...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Its a snuff movie. Prime paedophile material. Im told it retails at around £4,000.  I see you dont require a definition.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: You... You found that at Leons?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Theres more. Your brother also purchased a young boy for £15,000.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You seem surprised. Could it be you dont think that badly of him after all?  You neednt worry. It seems his motives were pure. From what I can make out he bought the boy to rescue him from further abuse.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: What... What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Your brother got mixed up with child procurers  and tried to make this world a better place, Mrs De Moraes. And having rescued one little life he unwisely set out to repeat the exercise.  You dont mess around with child procurers. Right now my guess is hes either on the run, held captive, or dead.  I understand your misgivings, Mrs De Moraes. But Ive seen the boy and made telephone contact with the man Leon bought him from. If anyone knows what happened to your brother it will be that man. Which leads me to why Im here at such a late hour. I need £20,000, in cash, by 11 this morning.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I need the money to smooth my way, you understand? Now, have you got that sort of cash here or do we need to meet in the morning?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I will of course do my best to hang onto it.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Where is it?  He. The boy you said my brother bought! Where is he?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I cant tell you that yet. But hes being well looked after.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Oh no. Youll have to do better than that, Mr Lombard.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Look, Mrs De Moraes, however much of a let down it might be, your brothers not back to his old weekend tricks! Impressionable as he is, he probably grew tired of healthy girls in grisly poses, tried moving on to bigger things, came upon more than hed bargained for and somehow fancied he could take on the real world. Which he no doubt chanced upon on his way to that thing now sitting on your table... Have a look at it, Mrs De Moraes. I told you I had bad news...

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: How dare you...  You dont know this tape belongs to my brother, do you, Mr Lombard?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: The question now is whether or not your brother still owns anything, Mrs De Moraes.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: No. The question now is how long its going to take you to get out of here, Mr Lombard.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Get out of my house. Youre fired, Mr Lombard.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Perhaps I should come back when youre...

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: No. Youre fired! Get out of my house. And take your sick tape with you...

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Laurence!

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I was hired by your parents, Mrs De Moraes.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: The family hired you and I have just fired you, Mr Lombard.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Why me, Mrs De Moraes? Why should such well-connected people as you hire a small- time French detective to look for their missing son, Mrs De Moraes?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Huh! Who do you think we are, Mr Lombard?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Couldnt Nazi hunters do the job?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: I still dont buy your story but I figured it cant do any harm to let you go on with your enquiry. Besides, if you do turn out to be nothing but a cheap little extortioner, we could always get the right people onto you. I trust you know who I am talking about.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You drive a hard bargain.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Thank you for coming. Come in and close the door, will you?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Last night you upset my sleep. Tonight my social life. We have two minutes. My dinner guests are waiting.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: You lost my money?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You could say that. And Friedman left this morning for Los Angeles.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Who is Friedman?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: The man who sold the boy to your brother.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Im impressed. That information could have cost me £20,000.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Well, I found a little more than that. Let me put it this way:...  Last night I thought your brother might be dead, tonight Im convinced he is. That said, I have no evidence and I advise you to let the police deal with it.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Are we understood?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You watched the tape?  Friedman and his people dont just provide little kids and videotapes, Mrs De Moraes. Theyre in the import-export business. They run hotels here in London which they probably use as ware- houses and ports of call for their merchandise.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Huh! Really? Hotels?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: The hotels are useful capital investments. The kids liquid assets. My guess is they own hotels across the globe, and travel agencies specialising in flights from the third world to boot.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Minimizes the risks. Children can be moved across borders using reliable businesses. These can also be used to move women and drugs... Anything that makes money really.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: W-why are you telling me all this, Mr Lombard?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: You drive a hard bargain, Mr Lombard.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You do want me to keep the job, dont you, Mrs De Moraes?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Mr Lombard?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Have you got a pen?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Just a moment...  Go ahead.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: The Mondrian, room 504. The number is 266 7548, plus the L.A. code...

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: ...7548. Have you... Have you found him yet?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Are you all right?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Yes... You woke me up... Its the middle of the night here. Have you found Mr Friedman?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Not yet. The place I hoped to find him turns out to be little more than a contact address. Ill give it 24 hours. He just might show up.  If you need to reach me ask for Mr Lamont. Paul Lamont, all right?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Paul Lamont...?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Yeah. Goodnight, Mrs De Moraes.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Mr Lombard. Mrs De Moraes...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Uh... Wait a moment, Mrs De Moraes...

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Mr Lombard...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: How are you, Mrs De Moraes?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: When did you get back?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Why dont you ask when I left the Mondrian?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Im really sorry you were not called...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Youre repeating yourself, Mrs De Moraes.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: I... Well, were burying Leon tomorrow and... Look, I wish I had more time, but its late and with the funeral...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Arent you curious to know about Friedman?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: I... If you dont mind, I do not think he matters now. It... Things turned out to be as we thought; Leon was weak. Theres no point in delving into his sad life anymore. Now, will you please tell me how much we owe you?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Black suits you.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Sorry?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Whats in the bag? Underwear? To seduce your husband? Or is it for your own recreation?  Tell me, how come such a handsome couple sleep in seperate bedrooms? Is it because he does it with little children?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Or is it the other way round? The children are needed because you cant satisfy him?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: You... You are out of order, Mr Lombard. I...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You what, Mrs De Moraes? YOU WHAT?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: How did you break into my office, Deborah? Ladies of your standing dont learn to pick locks between shopping trips.  Come on, Deborah! Acting dumb doesnt suit you! Who knew Id found dirt on your brother, huh? Who knew it was in an envelope? Taking me for dead, whod want to make sure it didnt fall into the wrong hands?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Youre mad...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Ive had a long and unpleasant day. Im tired and Im angry. But mad? Not yet.  I paid Leons boy a visit this morning. Found him alive and well. Why havent you told your husband where he is since reading my note, eh?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Why... I dont know what youre talking about.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You know hed have had him killed, dont you? Does a conscience still burn somewhere inside your sore mind, Deborah? Or is it just cold expediency? Could the boy perhaps come in useful when and if the day ever comes for you to face up to the man you married?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Have you finished?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: When did you learn about his taste for kids, huh? On your honeymoon? Or was it later, when bitterness set in and you turned against your beloved but weak little brother? How did you find out? Did he confess? Try to convert you perhaps? Or was it womans intuition? Or just the way he fucked you?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: You do have a vivid imagination, Mr Lombard. I only wish youd use it fruitfully instead of in being obnoxious. I fail to understand your purpose in this. Still, say what youre owed if you still wish to be paid or get out, all right?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I guess the news youd sent me after Friedman didnt go down too well, eh?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Whatever the reason, Im sorry I did. Goodbye, Mr Lombard. I believe you know your way out.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You knew he had nothing to do with your brothers disappearance, didnt you?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Huh! Dont you recall convincing me he had?  You should learn to live with your mistakes, Mr Lombard. There is some merit in it.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I take it you learnt to live with yours then. Take it all the mind-dulling pills in your medicine cabinet are surplus to your well-being...

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: How... When did you...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: It must be tough being married to Adonis to end up sleeping alone every night. Sleep must be hard coming. Whats harder? The thought of the fine litter you two could have bred if? Or imagining what he does with his children?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Tell me, did he kill his little victims too?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What do you mean, No, Mrs De Moraes?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: My brother hung himself.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Does the name Pierre Dreyer mean anything to you? Hes a client of mine and a friend of your husband.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Leon hung himself.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Adonis thought your brothers bodyd be found reasonably quickly when he hung it in Epping Forest, didnt he? Seemed like a good idea. An ex-junkie, obsessed with death; the perfect candidate for suicide. He just forgot one thing: forest ramblers are rare during your average blustery English November. An Englishman might have thought of that, but a Brazilian...

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Leon hung himself...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Leons not found, your parents worry, talk of hiring help to find him, even mention their manhunter friends perhaps... and Adonis panics, takes control, brings me in reckoning a small- time detective is unlikely to dig up anything awkward, not before Leons found anyhow. He must have kicked himself when he learned Id exceeded his expectations.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Leon hung himself...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Leon didnt hang himself, Deborah. Your husband killed him and made his death look like suicide. How did he do it, eh? Strangulation? Drugs? No doubt an autopsy will tell.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I doubt Friedman ever even met Leon, Deborah. Friedman dealt with select customers. As for my envelope, had he know where it was he wouldnt have mistaken me for a hitman called Lamont when we met in Los Angeles.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: ...You-you spoke to him?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Not in the strict sense of the word, no. He was in too much of a hurry to kill me when we first met and too wasted in acid when I caught up with him later.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Your brother stumbled upon Adoniss little secret, didnt he? And traded his silence for a kid and some cash. And Adonis fell for it, bought him his kid, sent him away, and then killed him when he came back for more.  Leon didnt come here to borrow money for prints. He came to extort a second kids life. Your flunkey let him in, so his visit couldnt be concealed, hence the exhibition story. There was no exhibition. Just as you suspected. Remember, Deborah? Leon does his own prints. Wouldnt want anyone to interfere with his Art.  I should have paid more attention to your words. Perhaps its the way you say them...

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: If-if my car is there, I could be the one who... Why dont you accuse me of killing my brother?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Kids are not your thing, Deborah. Youd have been ready for me when I turned up with Sleeping Beauty. Damn it! Then too I should have paid more attention. Not Leon, you said. It struck me at the time, but obviously not hard enough. You didnt say My God!, or whatever else well-bred ladies squeak on hearing Uncle Henry misbehaved. Not Leon. Who then?  You sure were right about one thing, Deborah, the job was too formidable for me. I should have thought a little more before I left for Los Angeles. But there I was focused so hard on Friedman Id stopped thinking. Nothing added up - Leon soliciting money for prints while buying kids at £15,000 a go; infiltrating the world of child traffickers; duping Friedman into selling him a little boy... You sure were right. The job was too formidable for me. But you knew that, didnt you?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Leon could still have hung himself.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Oh no. At long last Leon had found a mission. Hed never have killed himself when glory beckoned. Your husband killed your brother. And thanks to you, almost got me killed too.
